data.title: Chris Penn made Easton Sweet Shop his personal kitchen during ‘The Florentine’ filming | Lehigh Valley historical headlines
data.meta_description: Of all the Lehigh Valley stories to come out of the 1997 filming the famous flop “The Florentine,” this one is the tastiest.
data.text:
Of all the local stories to come out of filming the famous flop “The Florentine,” this one is the tastiest.

Actor Chris Penn took over the kitchen of one of the filming locations, the now-former Easton Sweet Shop in Centre Square, and made himself the unofficial chef for cast and crew. According to an Express-Times report 25 years ago this week, his eggplant parmesan lasagna took two days to make but was well worth the wait.

From the Nov. 25, 1997, report:

“Film acting is a performance. It’s a very public statement. Cooking is very private. It’s a personal statement,” [Penn] said. “It relaxes me. It’s very relaxing.

“This sauce I do as good as any performance,” Penn said … while slicing eggplant. “This sauce and a Porterhouse steak, nobody can beat me.”

… Clad in a sweat suit and sneakers, Penn moved around the Sweet Shop’s kitchen putting the final touches on the sauce. The secret to a great sauce is adding many different vegetables and cooking nice and slowly, he said. The sauce is so thick that the wooden fork stands straight up in it when it isn’t being used to stir.

Actors Tom Sizemore and Jim Belushi joined Penn in the kitchen for taste-testing. The movie’s cast also included Luke Perry, Michael Madsen, Burt Young and Mary Stuart Masterson.

Most scenes were shot in Bethlehem and Easton over five weeks. Mothers Bar and Grill off Easton’s Centre Square, served as the titular bar’s exterior while the Old Mount Vernon Ale House, now Two Rivers Brewing Co., was the interior.

MORE: ‘The Sopranos’ needed to dump a body. Dutch Springs was the perfect place.

Penn, the brother of actor Sean Penn, told the newspaper he learned cooking from his parents. Sweet Shop owner Peter Karavoulias was one of the few to learn the secret recipe to the Annucci sauce, named after Penn’s mother.

“You know what I love about these guys?” Karavoulias told The Express-Times. “Every single one of these guys is down to earth. They’re themselves. And I’m going to miss these guys when they’re gone.”

Penn was excited about “The Florentine,” telling the newspaper it was “a combination of the best part and one of the best scripts I’ve ever read.” Unfortunately, the movie, despite its cast and executive producer Francis Ford Coppola, was released direct to video in 1999. Penn died in 2006.

MORE LEHIGH VALLEY HISTORICAL HEADLINES THIS WEEK

• 10 YEARS AGO | Nov. 20-21, 2012: Extreme Easton-P’burg pranks. The Thanksgiving game rivalry goes too far when Easton’s red rover statue is stolen and returned damaged. A dead cat is found outside Phillipsburg High School in possible retaliation.

• 25 YEARS AGO | Nov. 21, 1997: BethWorks reworked. Over a decade before the SteelStacks campus and 20 years before the casino, Bethlehem Steel and redevelopment consultants unveil a plan for unused BethWorks buildings between the Hill-to-Hill and Minsi Trail bridges. Uses including sports, recreation, entertainment, retail and dining are proposed.

• 50 YEARS AGO | Nov. 24, 1972: SecState sentenced. New Jersey Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin is sentenced up to two years in state prison for trying to influence the award of a contract to repave an 8.6-mile stretch of Route 46 in White and Knowlton townships in Warren County. … Nov. 25: Dixie Cup founder dies. Hugh Moore, the founder of the Dixie Cup Co. and the namesake of Easton’s Hugh Moore Park, dies in New York City at age 85.

• 100 YEARS AGO | Nov. 20, 1922: Highway to Philly. After two years of work, a highway connecting Centre Square Easton and City Hall in Philadelphia — the early Route 611 — prepares for formal opening on Nov. 30, which, The Easton Express opines, “to automobilists and the general public, will be in every sense of the word a Day of Thanksgiving.” This comes about two months after the opening of New Jersey’s section of the William Penn Highway, a paved precursor to modern-day Route 57.

This story is part of Lehigh Valley Then, a periodic series that recalls historical headlines from lehighvalleylive.com, The Express-Times and their predecessors from 10, 20, 25, 50 and 100 years ago. Stories are pulled from microfilm at the Easton and Bethlehem area public libraries.
